Description: THIS AGREEMENT SUPPORTS THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE SHOSHONE PAIUTE TRIBES OF DUCK VALLEY'S NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION CONTROL PROGRAM.  MAJOR ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ASSESSMENT OF CURRENT NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION ISSUES THROUGHOUT THE RESERVATION AND UPDATING THE TRIBE'S NONPOINT SOURCE ASSESSMENT REPORT AND MANAGEMENT PROGRAM PLAN, WHICH WILL ULTIMATELY REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTANT LOADS TO THE TRIBAL WATERS.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $30,000.

THE FUNDS SUPPORT THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE ROUND VALLEY TRIBE'S NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. MAJOR ACTIVITIES INCLUDE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE TRIBE'S APPROVED NONPOINT SOURCE ASSESSMENT REPORT AND MANAGEMENT PLAN, WHICH WILL ULTIMATELY REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTANT LOADS TO THE TRIBAL WATERS TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY OF THE RESERVATION'S WATERS.   THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $130,000.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO SUPPORT THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE COLD SPRINGS NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION CONTROL PROGRAM. MAJOR ACTIVITIES INCLUDE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION TRAINING AND WATER QUALITY OUTREACH AND EDUCATION WHICH WILL ULTIMATELY REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTANT LOADS TO THE TRIBAL WATERS SPECIFICALLY IMPROVING WATER QUALITY OF THE RESERVATION'S WATERS.  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $30,000.00.

THESE FUNDS SUPPORT THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE WALKER RIVER PAIUTE TRIBE'S NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION CONTROL PROGRAM.  MAJOR ACTIVITIES INCLUDE IMPLEMENTING A SOLAR-POWERED WELL FOR LIVESTOCK, WHICH WILL ULTIMATELY REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTANT LOADS TO THE TRIBAL WATERS THEREBY IMPROVING THE WATER QUALITY OF THE RESERVATION'S WATERS.    THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $130,000.

THESE FUNDS SUPPORT THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE MOORETOWN RANCHERIA'S NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION CONTROL PROGRAM. MAJOR ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES WHICH WILL ULTIMATELY REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTANT LOADS TO THE TRIBAL WATERS SPECIFICALLY IMPROVING WATER QUALITY OF THE RESERVATION'S WATERS. THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $30,000 FOR THE PERIOD OF 10/1/19-9/30/20.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS GRANT IS TO SUPPORT THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE CHEMEHUEVI INDIAN TRIBE'S NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM.  MAJOR ACTIVITIES INCLUDE STABILIZATION OF RIPARIAN AREAS AND IMPLEMENTATION OF NONPOINT SOURCE COMPETITIVE PROJECT TO REESTABLISH A FUNCTIONING RIPARIAN ZONE WHICH WILL ULTIMATELY REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTANT LOADS TO THE TRIBAL WATERS SPECIFICALLY IMPROVING WATER QUALITY OF THE RESERVATION'S WATERS.    THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $130,000, WHICH INCLUDES $100,000 IN COMPETITIVE FUNDS.

THE FUNDS SUPPORT THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE FORT MOJAVE INDIAN TRIBE'S NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION CONTROL PROGRAM.  MAJOR ACTIVITIES INCLUDE IMPLEMENTATION OF NONPOINT SOURCE COMPETITIVE PROJECT FOR THE REDUCTION OF SEDIMENT AND NUTRIENTS TO WATERBODIES.  $100,000 IN TRIBAL CLEAN WATER ACT SECTION 319 FUNDS COMPETED UNDER EPA-OW-OWOW-18-01 IS OBLIGATED AS PART OF THIS FUNDING ACTION.  PREAWARD COSTS ARE APPROVED BACK TO 10/1/2018.

THESE FUNDS SUPPORT THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT OF THE TRIBE'S NONPOINT SOURCE CONTROL PROGRAM.  MAJOR ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DECREASING NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION BY INSTALLATION OF SOLAR PUMPS AS WELL AS UPDATING THE TRIBE'S ASSESSMENT REPORT AND MANAGEMENT PLAN.  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $30,000.

THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT DUCKWATER TRIBE TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE ANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERBODIES WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUN-OFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES. NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), TRAINING, AND EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $30,000.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.

THESE FUNDS SUPPORT THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT OF THE SUMMIT LAKE PAIUTE TRIBE'S NONPOINT SOURCE CONTROL PROGRAM. MAJOR ACTIVITIES INCLUDE UPDATING THE TRIBE'S NONPOINT SOURCE ASSESSMENT REPORT & MANAGEMENT PLAN AND CONTINUE COORDINATION WITH OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES TO MANAGE WILD HORSE NONPOINT SOURCE IMPACTS ON THE RESERVATION.  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $30,000.

THESE FUNDS SUPPORT THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT OF THE HAVASUPAI TRIBE'S NONPOINT SOURCE CONTROL PROGRAM. MAJOR ACTIVITIES INCLUDE STABILIAZATION OF TWO INUNDATED TRAILS ADJACENT TO HAVASU CREEK AND REMOVAL OF TWO FLOOD-CREATED EUTROPHIC POOLED WATER AREAS AT HAVASU SPRINGS ON THE HAVASUPAI RESERVATION AS WELL AS TRAINING AND TRAVEL FOR THE TRIBAL ENVIRONMENTAL STAFF.   THIS GRANT AGREEMENT PROVIDES FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $160,000.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.  $100,000 IN TRIBAL CLEAN WATER ACT SECTION 319 COMPETITIVE FUNDING COMPLETED UNDER EPA-OW-OWOW-18-01 IS OBLIGATED AS PART OF THIS FUNDING ACTION.

TO SUPPORT THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE RECIPIENT'S NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN WHICH WILL ULTIMATELY REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTANT LOADS TO TRIBAL WATERS ON THE TUOLUMNE BAND OF ME-WUK INDIANS RESERVATION.  IN ADDITION, PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE STABILIZING THE SHORELINE, MANAGING STORM DRAINS, TRAINING STAFF AND CONDUCTING PUBLIC OUTREACH AND EDUCATION TO INCREASE COMMUNITY KNOWLEDGE OF WATER POLLUTION PREVENTION STRATEGIES  THIS AWARD PROVIDES FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $25,779.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY BY IMPLEMENTING THE TRIBE'S NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN WHICH WILL ULTIMATELY REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTANT LOADS TO TRIBAL WATERS.  SPECIFICALLY THE TRIBE WILL IMPROVE WATER QUALITY BY IMPLEMENTING EROSION CONTROL MEASURES ON THE RESERVATION, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO VEGETATION CONTROL/MAINTENANCE, AND OTHER BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS).  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $30,000.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.

FUNDS SUPPORT THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE TRIBE'S NONPOINT SOURCE POLLLUTION CONTROL PROGRAM WHICH CONSISTS OF: DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF A NON-NATIVE PLANT SPECIES REMOVAL PLAN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF A NATIVE VEGETATION RE-ESTABLISHMENT PLAN. THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE WALKER RIVER PAIUTE TRIBE TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM AND SUPPORT THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT OF THE TRIBE'S PROGRAM. THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $30,000.

THESE FUNDS SUPPORT THE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE COCOPAH INDIAN TRIBE'S NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION CONTROL PROGRAM. THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $30,000.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT AND UPDATE THE TRIBE'S MANAGEMENT PLAN WHICH WILL REDUCE WATER POLLUTION IN THE WATERS OF THE TULE RIVER RESERVATION.  IN ADDITION, ACTIVITIES INCLUDE OUTREACH AND EDUCATION TO INCREASE PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE OF WATER POLLUTION PREVENTION STRATEGIES.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $30,000.

THESE ACTIVITIES WILL FURTHER THE TRIBE'S EFFORTS TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY OF CAHTO CREEK AND OTHER RESERVATION WATERS.  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEEMENT PROVIDES FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $30,000. THE PURPOSE IS TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY BY IMPLEMENTING THE TRIBE'S NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN WHICH WILL ULTIMATELY REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTANT LOADS TO TRIBAL WATERS SPECIFICALLY IMPROVING WATER QUALITY OF THE RESERVATION'S WATERS.  THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH IMPLEMENTING A PILOT OXBOW MEANDER RESTORATION PROJECT INCLUDING RIPARIAN PLANTING AND LIVESTOCK FENCING WHICH WILL HELP REDUCE WATER TEMPERATURES IN THE WALKER RIVER. DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF MONTANA TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUNOFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES.  NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS.ACTIVITIES:THE PROPOSED WORK IN THIS AGREEMENT  INCLUDES: 11 PROJECTS THAT WILL SUPPORT HIGHER WETLAND/RIPARIAN EFFECTIVENESS MONITORING COSTS TO BETTER DETERMINE LOAD REDUCTIONS FROM DIFFERENT WETLAND/RIPARIAN RESTORATION PROJECTS, WETLAND TREATMENT SYSTEMS, NITROGEN AND PHOSPHORUS LOAD REDUCTIONS, EXCESS SEDIMENT LOAD REDUCTIONS, TARGET SMALLER SCALE PROJECTS AT PRIORITY AREAS, AND TO IMPROVE STREAM CHANNELS TO MAINTAIN AND REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION. SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARD PROJECT NAME:
RESTORING RIPARIAN FUNCTION IN THE BULL RIVER WATERSHED
TRUMAN CREEK RESTORATION AT MONTANA BETTER BEEF
UPPER WILLOW CREEK HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECT
TETON SPRING CREEK RESTORATION PROJECT
STONE CREEK TREATMENT WETLAND DESIGN
THOMPSON #2 MINE RECLAMATION LOW-TECH PROCESS BASED RESTORATION PROJECT
UPPER EAST GALLATIN FLOODPLAIN AND WETLAND RESTORATION PROJECT
RESTORATION OF LOWER MANDEVILLE CREEK
RANCHING FOR RIVERS
BIG SKY WATERSHED CORPS MINI-GRANTS: BUILDING LOCAL CAPACITY TO REDUCE AND PREVENT NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION
TARGETED WATERSHED PROJECTS
OUTCOMES:THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE DELIVERABLES INCLUDE PROJECT DESIGNS, MONITORING REPORTS, PROJECT CONSTRUCTION COMPLETION REPORTS, AND WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENT FROM NUTRIENT AND SEDIMENT LOAD REDUCTIONS. SEE PROJECT WORKPLANS ATTACHED IN SEC. M FOR MORE DETAILS ON DELIVERABLES AND PROJECT LOAD REDUCTIONS. 

DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE ALL STATE RESIDENTS AND OCCUPANTS, BOTH PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF MONTANA TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUN-OFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES. NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS.ACTIVITIES:THIS GRANT IS USED FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF ACTIVITIES THAT ARE CONSISTENT WITH RECOMMENDATIONS DESCRIBED IN THE 2017 MONTANA NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN. MONTANA SUPPORTS AN EXTENSIVE SUBAWARD  PROGRAM WHICH FUNDS PROJECTS ACROSS THE STATE TO ADDRESS NONPOINT SOURCE ISSUES.  THESE IMPLEMENTATION ACTIVITIES OR PRACTICES ARE IDENTIFIED IN A DEQ-ACCEPTED WATERSHED RESTORATION PLAN (WRP).  THESE PROJECTS ADDRESS IMPAIRMENTS IDENTIFIED ON MONTANA'S 2020 LIST OF IMPAIRED WATERS. IN SOME INSTANCES, PROJECTS ON
STREAMS THAT ARE NOT LISTED AS IMPAIRED MAY BE ACCEPTABLE. THESE PROJECTS MUST REDUCE POLLUTANT LOADING TO AN IMPAIRED, DOWNSTREAM RECEIVING WATER OR PROTECT EXISTING USES FROM BECOMING IMPAIRED.SUBRECIPIENT:THE FOURTEEN SUBAWARDS FUNDED UNDER THIS GRANT WILL FUND ON-THE-GROUND PROJECTS, EDUCATION AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES, LOCAL CAPACITY BUILDING, STREAM BACK STABILIZATION AND RESTORATION PROJECTS ALL DESIGNED TO REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION.  SEE PROJECT TITLES IN TERMS AND CONDITIONS, SECTION F.

OUTCOMES:THE 319 NONPOINT SOURCE PROGRAM PROVIDES FUNDING FOR DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF PROJECTS THAT REDUCE AND PREVENT NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION IN IMPAIRED WATERBODIES WHILE IMPROVING WATER QUALITY AND RESTORING NATURAL STREAM AND LAKE PROCESSES.

THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES ARE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS THAT DESCRIBES THE WORK THAT HAS OCCURRED UNDER THE GRANT, DATA INPUT TO THE NATIONAL NONPOINT SOURCE DATABASE, EDUCATION AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES.  THE EXPECTED ENVIRONMENTAL OUTCOMES INCLUDE REDUCTIONS IN SEDIMENT, NITROGEN AND PHOSPHORUS FROM FOURTEEN SUBAWARDS.  THE INTENDED BENEFICIARY IS CLEANER WATER IN RIVERS AND STREAMS, IMPROVED HABITAT FOR AQUATIC SPECIES AND HEALTHY WATERSHEDS ACROSS THE STATE OF MONTANA AND ALL STATE RESIDENTS AND OCCUPANTS WHO BENEFIT FROM HEALTHIER WATERSHEDS.

ACTIVITIES:THE PROPOSED WORK IN THIS AGREEMENT INCLUDES 13 PROJECTS THAT WILL SUPPORT THE 2022 TEXAS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN. SUMMARIES OF ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED FOR EACH WORK PLAN INCLUDE(S):

23-01 ADMINISTRATION OF THE FISCAL YEAR 2023 CLEAN WATER ACT SECTION 319(H) AGRICULTURAL/SILVICULTURAL NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM: ADMINISTER AND MANAGE THE FISCAL YEAR 2023 CLEAN WATER ACT SECTION 319(H) COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT BETWEEN ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY AND TEXAS STATE SOIL WATER CONSERVATION BOARD.  COORDINATE WITH PROJECT COOPERATORS ON ADMINISTRATIVE RELATED ISSUES AND MANAGE THE FINANCIAL ASPECTS OF EACH CONTRACT. COORDINATE ADMINISTRATIVE ISSUES WITH THE TEXAS STATE SOIL WATER CONSERVATION BOARD NONPOINT SOURCE TECHNICAL STAFF THROUGH PERIODIC REVIEWS OF CONTRACTUAL REQUIREMENTS. UPDATE THE CURRENT PROPOSAL SUBMISSION PROCEDURES AND PRESENT TO INDIVIDUALS INTERESTED IN FUTURE FUNDING IN THE 319(H) AGRICULTURAL/SILVICULTURAL NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM.

23-02 FISCAL YEAR 2023 STATEWIDE AGRICULTURAL/SILVICULTURAL NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM: PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR FISCAL YEAR 2023 CLEAN WATER ACT SECTION 319(H) AGRICULTURAL/SILVICULTURAL PROJECTS AND TO ENSURE THAT THE PROJECTS MEET ALL TECHNICAL REQUIREMENTS AND ARE SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED IN A TIMELY FASHION. IMPLEMENT BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THROUGH THE STATE OF TEXAS NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION ABATEMENT PROGRAM.

23-03 LITTLE BRAZOS TRIBUTARIES CONTINUED WATER QUALITY MONITORING: PROVIDE WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY DATA COLLECTION THAT MEETS THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY REQUIREMENTS FOR DATA TO BE INCLUDED IN THE SURFACE WATER QUALITY MONITORING INFORMATION SYSTEM THAT IS ACCEPTABLE FOR USE IN FUTURE WATERBODY ASSESSMENTS. REINSTATE WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY DATA COLLECTION IN THE FIVE PROJECT WATERSHEDS TO GENERATE A DATA SET SUFFICIENT FOR THE STATE OF TEXAS TO ASSESS WATER QUALITY RELATIVE TO APPLICABLE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS AND TO BEGIN BUILDING A DATA SET FOR FUTURE PLANNING ACTIVITY IF DEEMED NECESSARY. DESCRIBE RECENT WATER QUALITY FINDINGS AND SHORT-TERM TEMPORAL TRENDS IN FINAL PROJECT REPORT ALONG WITH AN ASSESSMENT OF WHETHER WATER QUALITY WILL MEET DESIGNATED STANDARDS AND WHAT APPROPRIATE NEXT STEPS ARE FOR EVALUATED WATERSHEDS.

23-04 POND CREEK WATERSHED CHARACTERIZATION FOR FUTURE WATERSHED PROTECTION PLAN DEVELOPMENT: TO ADDRESS THE CONCERNS AND IMPAIRMENTS MOST EFFICIENTLY, THE WATERSHED MUST BE CHARACTERIZED TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL CAUSES AND SOURCES. IT IS A GOAL OF THIS PROJECT TO IDENTIFY EXISTING DATA AND IDENTIFY DATA GAPS FOR CHARACTERIZATION. TO GAIN PUBLIC SUPPORT OF THE PROJECT, THE TEXAS WATER RESOURCES INSTITUTE WILL FACILITATE A STAKEHOLDER GROUP (IF DETERMINED TO BE APPROPRIATE) AND IDENTIFY OBJECTIVES AND GOALS NEEDED FOR THE WATERSHED PLANNING PROCESS. THIS WILL ALSO INCLUDE HOSTING PUBLIC EDUCATION EVENTS WHERE STAKEHOLDERS WILL BE EDUCATED ON WATER QUALITY AND MITIGATION STRATEGIES. ULTIMATELY, IT IS THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT TO ACCOMPLISH ELEMENT A AND INITIATE ELEMENT B OF THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCIES NINE ELEMENTS FOR WATERSHED PLANS FOUND IN THE HANDBOOK FOR DEVELOPING WATERSHED PLANS TO RESTORE AND PROTECT OUR WATERS.

PROGRAMS.  THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THE FY2022 CWA SECTION 319(H) FUNDING ARE THE CITIZENS OF TEXAS. THIS GRANT HAS 13 SUBAWARDS LISTED IN A.23.D.
.ACTIVITIES:22-01 ADMINISTRATION OF THE FY2022 CWA SECTION 319(H) AGRICULTURAL/SILVICULTURAL NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM - THE TSSWCB NONPOINT SOURCE PROGRAM COORDINATOR IS RESPONSIBLE FOR ADMINISTERING THE CWA SECTION 319(H) AGRICULTURAL/SILVICULTURAL NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM. THIS WORKPLAN PROVIDES FUNDING FOR THE TSSWCB TO CONDUCT ADMINISTRATIVE ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE FY2022 SECTION 319(H) FEDERAL COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FUNDED BY EPA. ACTIVITIES REQUIRED TO ADMINISTER THE CWA &SECT;319(H) EPA FUNDED COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT INCLUDE EXECUTING THE FEDERAL AGREEMENT, IMPLEMENTING NECESSARY INTERAGENCY CONTRACTS AND COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS WITH COOPERATORS ON THE PROGRAM, FULFILLING ADMINISTRATIVE FUNCTIONS OF THE AGREEMENT AND INTERAGENCY AGREEMENTS (MEETING MILESTONES AND PROCESSING VOUCHERS) AS WELL AS MANAGING THE APPLICATION PROCESS FOR THE FY2023 EPA &SECT;319(H) FUNDING CYCLE. IN ADDITION, THIS WORKPLAN PROVIDES FOR SUPERVISORY OVERSIGHT OF THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE EPA AND TSSWCB AND THE INTERAGENCY CONTRACT BETWEEN THE TSSWCB AND COOPERATING ENTITIES.

22-02 FY2022 STATEWIDE AGRICULTURAL/SILVICULTURAL NPS MANAGEMENT PROGRAM - THE STATE HAS SUBSTANTIAL ACTIVITIES IN ANIMAL FEEDING OPERATIONS, CROP PRODUCTION, RANGELANDS AND IMPROVED PASTURES. SPECIFIC PROJECTS IN FY2022 WERE SELECTED BECAUSE THEY ADDRESS PROBLEMS ASSOCIATED WITH THESE LAND USES, AND BECAUSE ALL ARE WITHIN PRIORITY AREAS IDENTIFIED BY TSSWCB. THEREFORE, INFORMATION PROVIDED FROM THESE ACTIVITIES HAS BROAD APPLICABILITY THROUGHOUT THE STATE. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO TAKE THIS INFORMATION AND INFORM THE PUBLIC OF THE IMPACT THESE PROJECTS WILL HAVE IN REDUCING NPS POLLUTION. THE NPS POLLUTION ABATEMENT PROGRAM PROVIDES AGRICULTURAL AND SILVICULTURAL PRODUCERS THE OPPORTUNITY TO COMPLY WITH STATE WATER QUALITY LAWS THROUGH TRADITIONAL VOLUNTARY INCENTIVE-BASED PROGRAMS. THE TSSWCB COORDINATES THE PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES OF TEXAS' 216 SWCDS, THROUGH AN ORGANIZATIONAL STRUCTURE IN WHICH OWNERS AND OPERATORS OF THE STATE'S FARM AND GRAZING LANDS GOVERN THEMSELVES WITH RESPECT TO SOIL AND WATER RESOURCES. IT IS A PROGRAM OF VOLUNTARY PARTICIPATION AND IS A COST-EFFECTIVE MEANS OF ACHIEVING THE STATE GOAL TO ABATE AGRICULTURAL AND SILVICULTURAL NPS POLLUTION. THIS PROGRAM ALLOWS AGRICULTURAL AND SILVICULTURAL PRODUCERS IN TARGETED WATERSHEDS THE OPPORTUNITY TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT SITE-SPECIFIC WATER QUALITY MANAGEMENT PLANS (WQMPS) IN COOPERATION WITH LOCAL SWCDS. TSSWCB-CERTIFIED WQMPS ENSURE FARMING OR RANCHING OPERATIONS ARE CARRIED OUT IN A MANNER CONSISTENT WITH STATE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS. IF IT IS CONSISTENT, THE PLAN IS CERTIFIED AND IMPLEMENTED. FUNDS ARE ALLOCATED TO AREAS ACCORDING TO PRIORITIES SET BY THE TSSWCB. PRIORITY AREAS ARE DETERMINED BY THE TSSWCB AND ARE BASED ON ACTUAL AND POTENTIAL WATER QUALITY PROBLEMS FROM THE CWA &SECT;305(B) ASSESSMENT AND &SECT;303(D) LIST.

22-03 MEDINA RIVER BELOW MEDINA DIVERSION LAKE WATERSHED PROTECTION PLAN DEVELOPMENT - THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE PRODUCTION OF A STAKEHOLDER DRIVEN WPP DEVELOPED WITH BUY-IN FROM LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS AND GOVERNMENTAL ENTITIES. DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF TEXAS TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUN-OFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES. NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICE  INSTALLATIONS FOR ANIMAL WASTES, SEDIMENT, PESTICIDE AND FERTILIZER CONTROL, A VARIETY OF OTHER STRUCTURAL AND NONSTRUCTURAL PRACTICES, WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THE FISCAL YEAR 2023 CLEAN WATER ACT SECTION 319(H) FUNDING ARE THE CITIZENS OF TEXAS. THIS GRANT HAS 10 SUBAWARDS LISTED IN A.23.D.ACTIVITIES:(1.01) TEXAS STREAM TEAM PROGRAM: THE TEXAS STREAM TEAM PROGRAM COORDINATES A NETWORK OF PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS AND COMMUNITY SCIENTISTS WHO SEEK TO INCREASE THE PUBLIC'S KNOWLEDGE OF WATER QUALITY AND NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION ACROSS THE STATE THROUGH WATER QUALITY MONITORING, DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS, AND RELATED EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS. TEXAS STREAM TEAM WILL ENGAGE A STATEWIDE NETWORK OF A MINIMUM OF 400 COMMUNITY SCIENTISTS ANNUALLY. TEXAS STREAM TEAM WILL CONTINUE MANAGING, EXPANDING, AND STRENGTHENING THEIR STATEWIDE COMMUNITY SCIENCE NETWORKS BY WORKING WITH ESTABLISHED PARTNERS AND GROUPS; CREATING PARTNER NETWORKS AND COMMUNITY SCIENTIST GROUPS; EXPANDING THE ROLE OF COMMUNITY SCIENTISTS IN TEXAS; TRAINING THE PUBLIC, STUDENTS, VOLUNTEERS, AND RESOURCE MANAGERS ABOUT WATER QUALITY, NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION, AND WATERSHEDS; AND SHARING WATER QUALITY DATA THROUGH THE TEXAS STREAM TEAM DATAMAP AND WATERWAYS DATAVIEWER. TEXAS STREAM TEAM CAN OFFER A WIDE RANGE OF COMMUNITY SCIENTIST ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING A RIGOROUS CERTIFIED WATER QUALITY MONITORING PROGRAM, A RIPARIAN EVALUATION PROGRAM, A MACROINVERTEBRATE BIOASSESSMENT PROGRAM, ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS, COMMUNITY ACTION PROJECTS, STATEWIDE AND REGIONAL CONFERENCES, AND WORKSHOPS. TEXAS STREAM TEAM'S STATEWIDE WATERSHED SERVICES ARE TAILORED PROFESSIONAL SERVICES OFFERED TO WATERSHEDS ACROSS TEXAS. TEXAS STREAM TEAM WILL IDENTIFY POTENTIAL WATERSHEDS, ENGAGE STAKEHOLDERS, AND ASSESS WATERSHED NEEDS AND THEIR ALIGNMENT WITH TEXAS STREAM TEAM CAPABILITIES. THROUGH COORDINATION WITH THE TEXAS COMMISSION ON ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY'S NONPOINT SOURCE PROGRAM, THE TEXAS STREAM TEAM WILL HELP INTERESTED WATERSHED COORDINATORS FIND RESOURCES TO IMPLEMENT WATERSHED PROTECTION PLANS. TEXAS STREAM TEAM WILL PROMOTE SERVICES TO COMMUNITIES THAT HAVE:

#9679; COMPLETE AND APPROVED WATERSHED PROTECTION PLANS
#9679; WATERSHED PROTECTION PLANS UNDER DEVELOPMENT
#9679; INTEREST IN DEVELOPING A WATERSHED PROTECTION PLANS

TEXAS STREAM TEAM WILL ALSO HAVE DIRECT CONTACT WITH COMMUNITY SCIENTISTS AND PARTNERS THROUGH SUPPORT OF POTENTIAL AND ACTIVE COMMUNITY MONITORING PROGRAMS, COORDINATION OF REGIONAL MEETINGS, INFORMATION SESSIONS AND PRESENTATIONS, WORKSHOPS, FIELD ACTIVITIES, AND PARTNER MEETINGS. THESE ACTIVITIES WILL ADDRESS NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION PROBLEMS AND SOLUTIONS, LOCAL WATER QUALITY ISSUES, TRAINING NEEDS, MONITORING TECHNIQUES, EQUIPMENT USE, QUALITY CONTROL REQUIREMENTS, AND OTHER RELEVANT TOPICS. OUTREACH MATERIALS THAT SUPPORT AND ENHANCE THESE ACTIVITIES INCLUDE NEWSLETTERS, CURRICULUM RESOURCES, AND CONTINUED DEVELOPMENT ON THE EXISTING, COMPREHENSIVE TEXAS STREAM TEAM WEBSITE.

NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICE (BMP) INSTALLATIONS FOR ANIMAL WASTES, SEDIMENT, PESTICIDE AND FERTILIZER CONTROL, A VARIETY OF OTHER STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL PRACTICES, WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THE FY2022 CWA SECTION 319(H) FUNDING ARE THE CITIZENS OF TEXAS. THIS GRANT HAS 10 SUBAWARDS LISTED IN A.23.D.ACTIVITIES:PROJECT 1.01 - HEALTHY LAWNS AND HEALTHY WATERS (HLHW) EDUCATION PROGRAM 3

THE HLHW PROJECT TEAM WILL CONTINUE TO IMPROVE AND PROTECT SURFACE WATER QUALITY BY ENHANCING AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE OF RELEVANT BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS) BY REDUCING BACTERIA AND NUTRIENT NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION. THE TRAINING INCLUDES CRITICAL INFORMATION REGARDING BMPS FOR APPROPRIATE SELECTION, ESTABLISHMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF RESIDENTIAL LAWNS AND LANDSCAPING, AND METHODS FOR CAPTURING RAINWATER. THE HLHW EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM INCLUDES MATERIALS AND PRESENTATIONS REGARDING (1) LOCAL WATERSHED HYDROLOGY AND WPP EFFORTS, (2) RAINWATER HARVESTING TECHNIQUES FOR HOMEOWNERS, (3) LOCALLY APPROPRIATE LAWN AND LANDSCAPING MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, AND (4) EVALUATION AND ASSESSMENT OF THE PROGRAM SO THAT NEEDED MODIFICATIONS AND IMPROVEMENTS CAN BE MADE.

PROJECT 1.02 - EVALUATING BMP EFFECTIVENESS FOR COMMUNITY GARDENS IN DALLAS-FORT WORTH WATERSHEDS

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO ASSESS THE EFFECTIVENESS OF IMPLEMENTED COMMUNITY GARDENS BMPS IN THE WATERSHEDS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE MONITORING STORMWATER RUNOFF FROM SELECTED COMMUNITY GARDENS, ESTIMATING LOADINGS AND LOADING REDUCTIONS FROM COMMUNITY GARDEN BMPS, AND CONDUCTING OUTREACH IN THE WATERSHEDS BY CREATING EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS THAT WILL PROVIDE COMMUNITY GARDEN MANAGERS INFORMATION ON IMPLEMENTING BMPS.

PROJECT 1.03 - ARROYO COLORADO WATERSHED PROTECTION PLAN (WPP) IMPLEMENTATION -OSSF INVENTORY, NPS EDUCATION AND COASTAL STORMWATER BMP/LID INSTALLATION

THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT HIGH PRIORITY MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS IN THE ARROYO COLORADO WPP INCLUDING THE EXPANSION OF THE OSSF DATABASE TO THE INLAND PORTION OF THE WATERSHED. NEW INFORMATION OBTAINED WILL BE ADDED TO THE OSSF DATABASE AND MAPS TO FURTHER ENHANCE OSSF MANAGEMENT. PROJECT BASED STORMWATER MANAGEMENT AND EDUCATION PILOTED AT LOS FRESNOS ISD WILL BE REFINED AND REPLICATED AT THE NEW RIO HONDO MIDDLE SCHOOL. IMPLEMENTATION ACTIVITY WILL CONVERT GREY STORMWATER INFRASTRUCTURE INTO GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE BY RETROFITTING SWALES AND DETENTION BASINS WITH NATIVE COASTAL/RIPARIAN VEGETATION. EDUCATIONAL SIGNAGE AND CLASSROOM-BASED CONTENT WILL PROVIDE AN INTENSIVE EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE FOR FACULTY AND STUDENTS LEARNING ABOUT WATER QUALITY AND NATURAL SYSTEMS. THE WATERSHED COORDINATOR WILL CONTINUE OTHER EDUCATION, OUTREACH, AND ARROYO COLORADO WATERSHED PARTNERSHIP (ACWP) FACILITATION TO ENSURE LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY, FOSTER STAKEHOLDER PARTICIPATION, AND ENCOURAGE BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICE (BMP) ADOPTION THROUGH A VARIETY OF PROVEN APPROACHES TO SUPPORT NPS REDUCTION AND FURTHER WPP IMPLEMENTATION.

PROJECT 1.04 - LAMPASAS RIVER WATERSHED PROTECTION PLAN IMPLEMENTATION -ON-SITE SEWAGE FACILITIES REMEDIATION PHASE II

AGRILIFE EXTENSION WILL WORK WITHIN THE LAMPASAS RIVER WATERSHED TO CONTINUE PROGRAM EFFORTS FROM TCEQ CONTRACT 582-20-10176 TO INSPECT, REPAIR AND/OR REPLACE FAILING OR NON-EXISTENT ON-SITE SEWAGE FACILITIES (OSSFS) IN THE LAMPASAS RIVER WATERSHED. AGRILIFE EXTENSION WILL ALSO DELIVER EDUCATION PROGRAMS REGARDING PROPER MAINTENANCE OF OSSFS WITHIN THE WATERSHED.

DESCRIPTION:THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $3,938,700 TO NORTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (DEQ). THE STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA WILL IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUNOFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES.  NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS. THE ACTIVITIES PERFORMED INCLUDES DEVELOPING THE BASIN PLANNING BRANCH (BPB) IN THE DIVISION OF WATER RESOURCES (DWR) IN THE NORTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (DEQ). THE PLANS ARE PREPARED FOR EACH OF THE 17 MAJOR RIVER BASINS. THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE COMPILING AND REVIEWING WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY DATA COLLECTED BY DWR AND OUTSIDE AGENCIES FOR ASSIGNED RIVER BASINS TO ASSIST WITH IDENTIFYING PRIORITY WATERS FOR RESTORATION AND PROTECTION; CONTINUING TO COORDINATE WITH RIVER BASIN COALITIONS, RESOURCE AGENCY STAFF, AND WATERSHED MANAGEMENT GROUPS TO IDENTIFY HIGH PRIORITY WATERS AND ISSUES OF RELEVANCE TO THAT GROUP AND IDENTIFY POTENTIAL MEANS TO ADDRESS THE ISSUES. THE DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE ALL STATE RESIDENTS AND OCCUPANTS, BOTH PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY. THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES ARE TO BE IMPLEMENTED THROUGH SUBAWARDS: ACTIVITY NPSP-1 BASIN PLANNING, ACTIVITY NPSP-2.  NPS PROGRAM IMPLEMENTATION, ACTIVITY NPSP-3.  319 GRANT PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION, ACTIVITY NPSP-4.  GROUNDWATER NPS, POLLUTION PREVENTION, ACTIVITY NPSP-5. NPS MODELING, ACTIVITY NPSP-6.  FORESTRY NPS POLLUTION PREVENTION PROGRAM, ACTIVITY NPSP-7.  AGRICULTURAL NPS POLLUTION CONTROL, ACTIVITY NPSP-8.  EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION CONTROL, AND ACTIVITY NPSP-9. ON-SITE WASTEWATER DISPOSAL.
ACTIVITIES:THE PROPOSED WORK IN THIS AGREEMENT  INCLUDES: ACTIVITY NPSP-1. BASIN PLANNING (DWR)
THE PLANS ARE DEVELOPED BY THE BASIN PLANNING BRANCH (BPB) IN THE DIVISION OF WATER RESOURCES (DWR) IN THE NORTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (DEQ). THE PLANS ARE PREPARED FOR EACH OF THE 17 MAJOR RIVER BASINS. THEY ARE USED TO COMMUNICATE WITH POLICY MAKERS, THE REGULATED COMMUNITY AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC ON WATER QUALITY AND WATER QUANTITY STATUS AND CONCERNS ACROSS THE STATE. DESCRIPTION:THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $6,620,300 TO THE FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION. THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF FLORIDA TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUNOFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES.  NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS. ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES INCLUDE:
-	THE TWO DEPARTMENT PROGRAM PROJECTS ARE THE NPS, TOTAL MAXIMUM DAILY LOAD (TMDL) AND BASIN MANAGEMENT ACTION PLAN (BMAP) ADMINISTRATION ACTIVITIES AND THE BIOASSESSMENT PROGRAM. SECTION 1 OF THE NPS MANAGEMENT PLAN DESCRIBES THE TMDL AND BMAP WATERSHED ASSESSMENT AND RESTORATION PROCESSES, SECTION 2 OF THE NON-POINT SOURCE (NPS) MANAGEMENT PLAN DESCRIBES THE NPS GRANT AND FUNDING ADMINISTRATIVE ACTIVITIES AND SECTION 10 OF THE PLAN DESCRIBES THE BIOASSESSMENT PROGRAM ACTIVITIES. 
-	PROGRAM FUNDING WILL BE ASSIGNED TO ONE STORM WATER/LOW IMPACT DEVELOPMENT PROJECT.

THERE ARE 10 PROJECTS WITH OTHER GOVERNMENT ENTITIES, LOCAL AND STATE LEVEL, UNDER THE WATERSHED FUNDING CATEGORY. ALL OF THE WATERSHED PROJECTS ADDRESS NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION IN PRIORITY BMAP AREAS IDENTIFIED IN THE NPS MANAGEMENT PLAN. 
-	FOUR OF THE WORKPLAN PROJECTS ARE TARGETED AT REDUCING NUTRIENTS FROM URBAN STORM WATER WHICH IS IDENTIFIED IN THE PLAN AS A HIGH PRIORITY FOR THE DEPARTMENT. 
-	TWO OF THE PROJECTS ARE FOCUSED ON NONPOINT EDUCATION, ONE WITH FLORIDA-FRIENDLY LANDSCAPING AND THE OTHER IS FOCUSED ON RECLAIMED IRRIGATION WATER.
-	THERE ARE THREE SEPTIC TO SEWER PROJECTS ABANDONING SEPTIC TANKS IN THEIR RESPECTIVE AREAS. 
-	THERE IS ONE PLACEHOLDER WATERSHED FUNDING PROJECT THAT WILL BE ALLOCATED TOWARDS A LOCAL GOVERNMENT IMPLEMENTING AN ELIGIBLE PROJECT AT A LATER DATE.SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARDEES ARE UNKNOWN AT THIS TIME; STATE WILL PROCEED WITH SOLICITATION AND PROCUREMENT PROCESS.OUTCOMES:THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES INCLUDE:  
INSTALL MONITORING EQUIPMENT IN BOTH STORM WATER RETENTION AREAS AND WILL BE MONITORED FOR 8 MONTHS. COLLECT CONTROL DATA FROM SITE 1 ON STORM WATER MITIGATION WHEN NO TREES ARE PRESENT IN CONTRAST WITH DATA FROM SITE 2 POND.
PROJECT #4: THIS IS AN EDUCATION PROJECT. TRADITIONAL LOAD CALCULATIONS CANNOT BE PERFORMED FOR THIS PROJECT. SURVEYS WILL BE USED TO ASSESS BEHAVIOR CHANGE TO REDUCE PERSONAL POLLUTION. THE PROJECT IS FUNDING IMPLEMENTATION OF THE FLORIDA-FRIENDLY LANDSCAPING PROGRAM FOR ONE YEAR, WHICH HAS A STATEWIDE REACH (COVERING ALL BMAP WATERSHED AREAS) WITH EXTENSION AGENTS IN EVERY FLORIDA COUNTY AND HAS EXTENSIVE OUTREACH ASSISTING FLORIDA RESIDENTS, LANDSCAPE PROFESSIONALS, AND MUNICIPAL WORKERS HOW TO CHANGE BEHAVIOR TO REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION. 
PROJECT #5: IN-PERSON AND VIRTUAL EDUCATION WORKSHOPS ON RECLAIMED IRRIGATION WATER. WORKSHOP WILL HOST 20-500 PARTICIPANTS SUCH AS HOAS, LANDSCAPERS, AGRICULTURE, AND COMMUNITY ASSOCIATION MANAGERS WITH THE EXPECTED OUTCOME TO CHANGE THEIR BEHAVIORS.
PROJECT #7: MARTIN COUNTY UTILITIES WILL MEASURE THE REDUCTION IN NITROGEN AND PHOSPHORUS WILL BE MEASURED IN THE MONITORING WELLS AND THROUGH MODELING USING THE GIS BASED SOFTWARE.
PROJECT #8 THE CITY OF ORLANDO WILL CONDUCT SURVEYS WITH PROPERTY OWNERS TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF OUTREACH AND THE REASONS FOR DECIDING WHETHER TO CONNECT TO MUNICIPAL SEWER. IN ADDITION, THE CITY OF ORLANDO WILL TRACK INFORMATION RECEIVED FROM CONTRACTORS ON THE CONDITION OF ONSITE SEWAGE TREATMENT AND DISPOSAL SYSTEMS THAT WERE DECOMMISSIONED TO ASCERTAIN IF THERE WERE SIGNIFICANT LEAKAGES.

THIS WORKPLAN PROVIDES FUNDING FOR LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (LDEQ)  TO CONDUCT ADMINISTRATIVE ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH THE FY2022 SECTION 319(H) FEDERAL COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FUNDED BY ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA). ACTIVITIES REQUIRED TO ADMINISTER THE CWA  319(H) EPA FUNDED COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT INCLUDE EXECUTING THE FEDERAL AGREEMENT, IMPLEMENTING NECESSARY INTERAGENCY CONTRACTS AND COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS WITH COOPERATORS ON THE PROGRAM, FULFILLING ADMINISTRATIVE FUNCTIONS OF THE AGREEMENT AND INTERAGENCY AGREEMENTS (MEETING MILESTONES AND PROCESSING VOUCHERS) AS WELL AS MANAGING THE APPLICATION PROCESS FOR THE FY2023 ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA)  319(H) FUNDING CYCLE. IN ADDITION, THIS WORKPLAN PROVIDES FOR SUPERVISORY OVERSIGHT OF THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA) AND TSSWCB AND THE INTERAGENCY CONTRACT BETWEEN THE LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY (LDEQ) AND COOPERATING ENTITIES.SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THE FY2022 CLEAN WATER ACT (CWA) SECTION 319(H) FUNDING ARE THE CITIZENS OF LOUISIANA. 22-01 ADMINISTRATION OF THE FY2022 CLEAN WATER ACT (CWA) SECTION 319(H) AGRICULTURAL/SILVICULTURAL NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM: MAINTAIN ACCURATE CONTRACT FILES, FINANCIAL REPORTS AND BUDGET SPREADSHEETS AND MEET ALL DEADLINES AS MANDATED BY ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA). EXECUTE INTERAGENCY CONTRACTS WITH THE COOPERATING AGENCIES AFTER RECEIVING THE EXECUTED COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FROM ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA). MAKE AVAILABLE THE UPDATED PROPOSAL SUBMISSION PROCEDURES FOR PROPOSED PROJECTS DURING THE PROJECT PERIOD. 22-02 FY2022 STATEWIDE AGRICULTURAL/SILVICULTURAL NPS MANAGEMENT PROGRAM: SUCCESSFUL PROJECTS DUE TO OVERSIGHT OF PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND IMPLEMENTATION OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS) THROUGH THE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION ABATEMENT PROGRAM.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF INDIANA TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUN-OFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES.  NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS.ACTIVITIES:THE ACTIVITIES OF THE PROJECTS WILL PROVIDE THE FOLLOWING: IMPROVED WATER QUALITY AND REDUCED CONTAMINANT LOADS (E.G., NUTRIENTS, BACTERIA (E. COLI), AND SEDIMENT); DEVELOPMENT OF WATERSHED MANAGEMENT PLAN DOCUMENTS; INCREASE IN EDUCATION AND OUTREACH TO LOCAL CITIZENS CONCERNING NPS ISSUES; IMPLEMENTATION OF BMPS ADDRESSING TARGET LOADS AND GOALS OF WMPS (E.G., CREATE AND ENHANCE RIPARIAN BUFFERS ALONG STREAM CHANNELS TO DECREASE NUTRIENT AND SEDIMENT INPUTS TO SURFACE WATERS); IMPROVE THE ACCESSIBILITY AND LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES WITHIN THE PATHWAY TO WATER QUALITY; RESTRICTING LIVESTOCK FROM STREAMS AND PONDS THAT WILL HELP ELIMINATE NUTRIENTS IN THE WATER; REDUCE EROSION ON CROPLAND BY INCREASING RESIDUE ON CROP FIELDS WITHIN THE WATERSHED; INCREASE IN URBAN/SUBURBAN BMP IMPLEMENTATION TO REDUCE THE WATER QUALITY IMPACT OF EXCESS STORM WATER; INCREASED WATER QUALITY AWARENESS AND CHANGES IN BEHAVIOR; ASSESSMENTS OF BIOLOGICAL COMMUNITIES AND HABITAT; AND REDUCTION IN LITTER AND TRASH WITHIN WATERSHEDS.

SUBRECIPIENT:THE VARIOUS LISTED PROJECTS WILL CONSISTS OF DEVELOPING WATERSHED MANAGEMENT PLANS, DEVELOPING, PROMOTING, AND IMPLEMENTING COST-SHARE PROGRAMS AND DEVELOPING EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS:  VERNON FORM MUSCATATUCK RIVER WATERSHED PROJECT; SALT-PIPE CREEK WATERSHED PROJECT; FISH CREEK WATERSHED - PLANNING THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO CONSIST OF ESTABLISHING A WATER QUALITY MONITORING/ASSESSMENT PROGRAM TO COLLECT BASELINE DATA FOR FISH CREEK; BLACK CREEK WATERSHED - PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION; PATOKA WATERSHED CLEAN SWEEP:  HIRE A PART-TIME WATERSHED COORDINATOR TO CONDUCT VARIOUS ACTIVITIES INCLUDING PLANNING VOLUNTEER CLEAN UP EVENTS AND EDUCATION/OUTREACH EVENTS; 
INDIANA CLEAN LAKES PROGRAM:  DEVELOP A QAPP FOR THE LAKE WATER QUALITY ASSESSMENT FOR THE 2023-2024 SAMPLING SEASON, COLLECT AND ANALYZE WATER SAMPLES FROM LAKES AD RESERVOIRS DURING THE MONTHS OF JULY AND AUGUST, ADMINISTER THE VOLUNTEER LAKE MONITORING PROGRAM ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE WATERS, AND CONDUCT EDUCATION/OUTREACH ACTIVITIES; LOWER SALAMONIE RIVER WATERSHED IMPLEMENTATION PROJECT; LAKE MONROE WATERSHED MANAGEMENT PLAN IMPLEMENTATION; LOST RIVER WATERSHED IMPLEMENTATION AND REGION OF THE GREAT BEND OF THE WABASH RIVER IMPLEMENTATION.
OUTCOMES:THE CITIZENS OF INDIANA ARE THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THESE PROJECTS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF MICHIGAN TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUNOFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES.  NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS.ACTIVITIES:THE PROPOSED WORK IN THIS AGREEMENT  INCLUDES: 12 PROJECTS THAT WILL SUPPORT WATERSHED RESTORATION AND PROTECTION AND WATERSHED MANAGEMENT PLANS, NUTRIENT REDUCTION,  COORDINATION WITH PARTNER AGENCIES AND TARGETED WATERSHEDS.SUBRECIPIENT:THE ELEVEN PROPOSALS WERE SELECTED FOLLOWING A REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS AND WILL IMPLEMENT ACTIVITIES RECOMMENDED IN WATERSHED MANAGEMENT PLANS APPROVED AS MEETING BOTH STATE AND FEDERAL CRITERIA. THE PROPOSED ACTIVITIES INCLUDE IMPLEMENTING A MIX OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMP) AND OUTREACH AND EDUCATION RECOMMENDATIONS. PROPOSED BMPS INCLUDE BOTH TRADITIONAL AND INNOVATIVE AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES, LOW IMPACT DEVELOPMENT, AND STREAM CHANNEL RESTORATION. THREE OF THE PROJECTS WILL IMPLEMENT PROTECTION PRACTICES (WATER QUALITY BASED PERMANENT CONSERVATION EASEMENTS) TO PREVENT FUTURE NONPOINT SOURCE IMPACTS. THE REMAINING PROJECTS WILL WORK TO RESTORE WATERS THAT ARE NOW IMPAIRED. THE ADD-ON TO THE EXISTING PROJECT IN THE WESTERN LAKE ERIE BASIN WILL PROVIDE $216,000 FOR OUTREACH EFFORTS AND INNOVATIVE NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT TO REDUCE PHOSPHORUS LOADS TO THE BASIN.OUTCOMES:THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPLEMENTATION OF WATERSHED MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR WATERSHEDS ON THE NONATTAINMENT LIST INCLUDING WATERSHEDS WITH APPROVED TOTAL MAXIMUM DAILY LOAD ALLOCATIONS; PROJECTS THAT YIELD MEASURABLE IMPROVEMENT IN WATER QUALITY; PROJECTS THAT IMPLEMENT METHODS TO ADDRESS LAND USE CHANGES THAT THREATEN OR HAVE IMPACTED WATER QUALITY; WATERSHED PROJECTS THAT IMPLEMENT LOW IMPACT DEVELOPMENT PRACTICES TO PROTECT WATER QUALITY; PROJECTS THAT TAKE A SYSTEMATIC AND COMPREHENSIVE APPROACH TO DEALING WITH AGRICULTURAL SOURCES; PROJECTS THAT IMPLEMENT DRAINAGE WATER MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES; PROJECTS THAT YIELD MEASURABLE CHANGES IN KNOWLEDGE OR BEHAVIOR TO ADDRESS NPS POLLUTANTS OR CAUSES OF IMPAIRMENTS; AND PROJECTS TO REDUCE PHOSPHORUS LOADS FROM THE WESTERN LAKE ERIE BASIN; IMPLEMENT AGRICULTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN THE UPPER ST. JOSEPH OF THE MAUMEE WATERSHED, INNOVATIVE NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO REDUCE PHOSPHORUS AS WELL AS SEDIMENT AND NITROGEN LOADS FROM AGRICULTURAL SOURCES TO MEET THEIR 20 PERCENT PHOSPHORUS REDUCTION GOAL. 

DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE ALL STATE RESIDENTS AND OCCUPANTS, BOTH PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY.

DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE ALL MARYLAND RESIDENTS AND OCCUPANTS, BOTH PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO PUEBLO OF SANTA CLARA TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUN-OFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES. SPECIFICALLY, THE PUEBLO WILL IMPLEMENT BEST MANAGEMENT PROJECTS (BMPS) ALONG STRETCHES OF RIO SANTA CRUZ  TO MITIGATE NONPOINT IMPACTS CAUSED BY FLOODING AND FLOOD CONTROL EFFORTS BY RE-VEGETATING AND STABILIZING THE IMPACTED SEGMENTS THROUGH A CONTRACTOR. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY IN THE RIO SANTA CRUZ. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE PEOPLE AND RESIDENTS OF SANTA CLARA PUEBLO. THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENTS.


ACTIVITIES:THE PROPOSED WORK IN THIS AGREEMENT  INCLUDES: IMPLEMENT BEST MANAGEMENT PROJECTS (BMPS) ALONG STRETCHES OF RIO SANTA CRUZ  TO MITIGATE NONPOINT IMPACTS CAUSED BY FLOODING AND FLOOD CONTROL EFFORTS BY RE-VEGETATING AND STABILIZING THE IMPACTED SEGMENTS. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE FOLLOWING THE PUEBLO PROCUREMENT PROCESS TO ACCOMPLISH THE FOLLOWING UNDER CONTRACT:
PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF IMPLEMENTATION OF NON-POINT SOURCE POLLUTION BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (ROCK DAMS, LOG DAMS, ROCK BAFFLES, BANK ARMORING) ALONG PREVIOUSLY UNTREATED AREAS THE RIO SANTA CRUZ. COSTS TO INCLUDE:
-APPROXIMATELY 5 TONS MEDIUM ROCKS (8-14' DIAMETER), 3 TONS LARGE ROCKS (14-30' DIAMETER) AND 2 TONS VERY LARGE ROCKS (30'+ DIAMETER) FOR BMP CONSTRUCTION (THIS CONSTITUTES THE TRIBAL MATCH)
- HEAVY EQUIPMENT COSTS FOR TRANSPORT OF NATURAL MATERIALS (WOODY DEBRIS, ROCK) FROM SANTA CLARA CANYON FOR USED IN CONSTRUCTING NON POINT SOURCE (NPS) BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. 
- ERADICATION OF WATER GORGING NON-NATIVE TREE AND PLANT SPECIES SUCH AS RUSSIAN OLIVE, ELM AND TAMARISK. NON-CHEMICAL EXTRACTION ONLY WITHIN THE ORDINARY HIGH WATER MARK.
- BANK RESTRUCTURING AND ARMORING TO REDUCE CUTTING AND DECREASE GRADE ALONG BANKS. 
- INSERTION OF ROCK DAMS AND ROCK BAFFLES IN RIO SANTA CRUZ ON BOTH SIDES OF RIVERSIDE BRIDGE TO REDUCE FLOWS FOR SEDIMENT DEPOSITION, NUTRIENT RETENTION, RE-VEGETATION AND BANK STABILIZATION. 
- MONITORING OF PREVIOUS NON POINT SOURCE (NPS) WORK AREAS ALONG RIO SANTA CRUZ. 
- PURCHASE OF POLES, SAPLINGS, SEEDLINGS, GRASSES AND FORBS. THIS TASK MAY BE SUBSTITUTED TO BUILD MORE ROCK DAMS AND BAFFLES IF VEGETATION MATERIAL IS NOT AVAILABLE DURING CONTRACT PERIOD.
THERE ARE NO SUBRECIPIENTS EXCEPT FOR THE CONTRACTOR SELECTED DURING THE BID PROCESS OUTLINED IN THE WORKPLAN.  SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE: PUEBLO LEADERSHIP INFORMED OF 319 BASE NON POINT SOURCE (NPS) POLLUTION PROGRAM TASKS TO IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND GENERATE SUPPORT OF FUTURE WORK IN THE PUEBLO SURFACE WATERS, COMMUNITY AWARENESS OF NPS POLLUTION IMPACTS AND PROJECTS TO IMPROVE PUEBLO SURFACE WATERS THOUGH EPA FUNDING, EFFECTIVE DEMONSTRATION OF 319 NON POINT SOURCE (NPS) PUEBLO PROGRAM AND TASKS TO PROTECT AQUATIC RESOURCES OF THE RIO SANTA CRUZ, SCOPE OF WORK PLAN COMPLETED FOR RIO SANTA CRUZ 319 NPS PROJECT, COMPLETED OPEN AND FAIR PROCUREMENT PROCESS TO HIRE CONTRACTOR FOR 319NON POINT SOURCE (NPS) WORK, COMPLETION OF 319 NPS PROJECT ALONG RIO SANTA CRUZ, DOCUMENTATION OF 319 NPS PROJECT WITH COMPLETED FINAL REPORT OF RIO SANTA CRUZ NON POINT SOURCE (NPS) PROJECT AND IMPROVEMENT IN ATTAINING PUEBLO WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ON WATER BODY IMPACTED BY NON POINT SOURCE (NPS) POLLUTION.

DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE ALL TRIBAL RESIDENTS AND OCCUPANTS, BOTH PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY.

DESCRIPTION:THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF  $6,617,700 TO THE FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION. THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF FLORIDA TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUNOFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES.  NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS.ACTIVITIES:THE PROPOSED WORK IN THIS AGREEMENT INCLUDES PROJECT (NON-POINT SOURCE) NPS/WATERSHED PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION. SUPPORT OF THE NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT SECTION INCLUDES MANAGING THE RESTORATION CONTRACTS ASSOCIATED WITH THE PROGRAM AND WATERSHED FUNDING, OVERSEEING THE NWQI PROGRAM, AND ADDITIONAL TASKS SUCH AS UPDATING THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY (EPA) GRANTS REPORTING TRACKING SYSTEM. THIS FUNDING PROVIDES SUPPORT FOR STAFF, TRAVEL, AND OTHER EXPENSES THAT ARE OTHERWISE UNAVAILABLE. IN ADDITION, THE DIVISION OF ENVIRONMENTAL ASSISTANCE AND RESTORATION (DEAR) STAFF COORDINATES WITH STATE, REGIONAL, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES, LOCAL WATERSHED GROUPS, AND NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS AND OTHER INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT (TOTAL MAXIMUM DAILY LOADS) TMDLS, BMAPS, AND REASONABLE ASSURANCE PLANS (9-ELEMENT WATERSHED PLANS). THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES ACTIVITIES IDENTIFIED IN SECTION 1 AND 2 OF THE NPS MANAGEMENT PLAN AND IMPLEMENTS MILESTONES SET FORTH IN APPENDIX 1 OF THE PLAN. WHILE THE BIOASSESSMENT PROGRAM WILL CONTINUE TO REPORT ON ANNUAL PROGRESS ON MEETING GOALS AS DEFINED IN THE MANAGEMENT PLAN, THIS GRANT WILL NO LONGER COVER STAFF SALARIES.  PROJECT 2, COUNTY LINE ROAD SEDIMENT REDUCTION PROJECT.   THIS PROJECT WILL MINIMIZE SOIL EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION DELIVERY FROM UNPAVED ROAD SURFACE AND ROADSIDE DRAINAGE SYSTEM BY DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION OF ADEQUATELY STABILIZED ROADSIDE DRAINAGE AND STABILIZATION OF THE DIRT ROAD WITH PERVIOUS OPEN GRADE ASPHALT PAVEMENT. THE DESIGN INCLUDES INSTALLATION OF SODDED ROADSIDE SHOULDERS AND VEGETATED SWALES FOR THE TREATMENT AND CONVEYANCE OF STORMWATER RUNOFF. THESE BMPS WILL ALLOW FOR ELIMINATION OF ROADSIDE EROSION AND SEDIMENTATION, REDUCTION OF NITRIFICATION, REDUCTION OF VELOCITIES OF THE ROADWAY RUNOFF, IMPROVED INFILTRATION OF THE STORMWATER RUNOFF THROUGH VEGETATION.
SUBRECIPIENT:SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE:
PROJECT 1: NPS/WATERSHED PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION
PROJECT 2: COUNTY LINE ROAD SEDIMENT REDUCTION  PROJECT
PROJECT 3: CONTINUED EXPANSION AND SUSTAINABILITY OF THE FLORIDA-FRIENDLY LANDSCAPING TRADE; PROGRAM TO PROTECT WATER QUALITY FROM STORMWATER RUNOFF AND NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION
PROJECT 4: ABANDONMENT OF  SEPTIC TANKS, INSTALLATION OF THE INDIVIDUAL LATERALS, REPAIR OF THE ROADWAY FOR THE LATERAL CONNECTIONS ONLY AND PHYSICAL CONNECTION OF THE HOMES TO THE SEWER SYSTEM. 
PROJECT 5: BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICE INCLUDES A SUMMIT HIGH-PERFORMANCE UP-FLOW FILTER SYSTEM WHICH IS TYPICALLY COMPRISED OF BOLD AND GOLDREG; MEDIA
OUTCOMES:THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLE INCLUDE ANNUAL REPORTS SUBMITTED THROUGH GRTS. THEY EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE EXPECTED ENVIRONMENTAL RESULTS (LOAD REDUCTIONS AND OTHER WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENT INFORMATION), EDUCATED STAKEHOLDERS ON NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION, FORMED PARTNERSHIPS, AND ANY GENERAL BMAP AND/OR RAP INFORMATION. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE ALL STATE RESIDENTS AND OCCUPANT, BOTH PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY.

DESCRIPTION:THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD  IN THE AMOUNT OF $3,960,300 TO SUPPORT THE STATE OF GEORGIA'S IMPLEMENTATION OF IT'S NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUNOFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES.  NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS.ACTIVITIES:THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO 1) COLLECT WATER QUALITY DATA TO ESTABLISH BASELINE AND TREND CONDITIONS AND TO SUPPORT WATERSHED PLANNING, MODELING, TMDL DEVELOPMENT AND OTHER GAEPD ACTIVITIES; 2) DOCUMENT WATER USE IMPAIRMENT AND REASONS FOR PROBLEMS CAUSING LESS THAN FULL SUPPORT OF DESIGNATED WATER USES; 3) PROVIDE ASSISTANCE IN REVIEWING WATERSHED ASSESSMENTS AND PROTECTION PLANS; 4) ASSIST WITH TRAINING FOR SECTION 319(H) PROJECTS ON PROPER SOPS FOR WATER QUALITY COLLECTION AND RELATED ACTIVITIES; AND 5) CONDUCT POST-BMP MONITORING IN SUPPORT OF THE NATIONAL WATER QUALITY INITIATIVE (NWQI). SUBRECIPIENT:COASTAL RESOURCES DIVISION; UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA; 319 COMPETITIVE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS TBD
OUTCOMES:EXPECTED OUTCOMES: PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO DEVELOP TMDLS THAT WILL BE USED BY STATE AND LOCAL ENTITIES TO RESTORE IMPAIRED WATERS AND LEAD TO THEIR BEING REMOVED FROM THE STATE LIST OF IMPAIRED WATERS. THE TMDLS DEVELOPED WILL HELP SET FUNDING PRIORITIES FOR USE OF NPS GRANT MONIES. EXPECTED OUTCOMES: TMDLS FOR ALL 'IMPAIRED' WATERS ON GEORGIA'S 303(D) LIST, PRODUCED OVER A 5-YEAR PERIOD BASED ON THE BASIN ROTATION CYCLE. ANNUAL REPORTS AND FINAL CLOSEOUT REPORT DATA COLLECTED AND UPLOADED TO GAEPD AND USEPA DATABASES AS APPROPRIATE. RFP DOCUMENTS; DATA COLLECTED, ANALYZED BY ACCREDITED LAB, AND UPLOADED TO GAEPD AND USEPA DATABASES AS APPROPRIATE   PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO DEVELOP TMDLS THAT WILL BE USED BY STATE AND LOCAL ENTITIES TO RESTORE IMPAIRED WATERS AND LEAD TO THEIR BEING REMOVED FROM THE STATE LIST OF IMPAIRED WATERS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS ACTION APPROVES AN AWARD IN THE AMOUNT OF $3,231,000 TO SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUN-OFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES. NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS. ACTIVITIES:THE PROPOSED WORK IN THIS AGREEMENT INCLUDES: THREE PROJECTS THAT WILL SUPPORT: IMPLEMENTATION OF NUTRIENT/POLLUTANT REDUCTION STRATEGY, 319 NPS FUNDING WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT PROJECTS IN ALL REGIONS OF THE STATE. NPS CONTROL MEASURE ALONG WITH AWARENESS, OUTREACH, AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES AS IDENTIFIED IN APPROVED 9 KEY ELEMENT WATERSHED PLANS IN THE FOLLOWING WATERSHEDS: UPPER PINEY CREEK WATERSHED, FULLER CREEK-TOWN CREEK WATERSHED, AND MUDDY BAYOU WATERSHED. SUBRECIPIENT:SUB-AWARDS ARE NOT KNOW AT THE TIME OF OF WORK PLAN APPROVAL DUE TO STATE PROCUREMENT AND SOLICITATION PROCESS.OUTCOMES:OUTCOMES: ENTRY OF REQUIRED DATA ELEMENTS INTO EPAS GRTS DATABASE, DEVELOPMENT OF WATERSHED-BASED PLANS, NPS PROGRAM SUCCESS STORIES, ENVIRONMENTAL TEACHER WORKSHOPS, ONSITE WASTEWATER DISPOSAL SYSTEM INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE EDUCATION AND AGRICULTURAL NPS IMPLEMENTATION ASSISTANCE. DELIVERABLES: REPORTS WILL INCLUDE: A SUMMARY OF ACTIVITIES OVER THE PAST YEAR IN EACH OF THE MISSISSIPPI NPS PROGRAM ELEMENTS, EXPLANATION OF HOW THE ACTIVITIES OVER THE PAST YEAR CONTRIBUTE TO ACHIEVEMENT OF NPS PROGRAMS GOALS AND A SUMMARY OF THE PROGRESS IN ACHIEVING MISSISSIPPI NPS PROGRAM MILESTONES. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE ALL STATE RESIDENTS AND OCCUPANTS, BOTH PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY.

THIS PROJECT IS A ONE-YEAR PROJECT.  THE PROPOSAL WILL FUND GENERAL CAPACITY BUILDING UNDER GAP, AS WELL AS ELEMENTS OF PROGRAMMATIC WORK UNDER CWA 106 AND 319.  106 AND 319 ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE MONITORING, CAPACITY BUILDING, AND OUTREACH.  NOTE: THE INDIRECT COST RATE AGREEMENT ON FILE WITH EPA EXPIRED 12/31/2018 AND YOU MAY NOT DRAW DOWN FUNDS FOR INDIRECT COSTS WITHOUT A CURRENT, APPROVED RATE IN PLACE.

THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF NEW MEXICO TO IMPLEMENT A NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECT IN THE ANIMAS-SAN JUAN WATERSHED AS A RESULT OF THE GOLD KING MINE RELEASE. NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS. PROJECTS IN THE ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT ARE PART OF THE EPA-ACCEPTED LOWER ANIMAS WATERSHED BASED PLAN. SUBAWARD ACTIVITIES INCLUDE FLOODPLAIN RESTORATION/EROSION MITIGATION IN THE TUCKER WATERSHED RIVERBANK, WETLAND RESTORATION AND RIPARIAN MANAGEMENT IN THE FLORA VISTA NORTH BANK FLOODPLAIN AND AN OUTREACH/EDUCATION CAMPAIGN FOR BOTH PROJECTS. ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THE ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT INCLUDE QUANTITATIVE NUTRIENT LOAD REDUCTIONS AND INCREASED AWARENESS OF WATERSHED BASED PLANNING. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE RESIDENTS OF NEW MEXICO.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND THE PUEBLO OF SANTA ANA'S NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION CONTROL PROGRAM. THE PUEBLO OF SANTA ANA WILL ASSESS STORMWATER DRAINAGES AND FLOW PATHS AND IDENTIFY POSSIBLE BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION. THE EXPECTED DELIVERABLES ARE INSPECTIONS OF AT LEAST TWO DRAINAGES PER MONTH AND CONDUCTING AT LEAST ONE OUTREACH EVENT. THE OUTCOME OF THIS PROJECT IS AN INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF THE PUEBLO'S NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION AND INCREASED AWARENESS OF PUEBLO RESIDENTS OF THE EFFECTS OF NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE THE RESIDENTS OF THE PUEBLO OF SANTA ANA. THIS AWARD DOES NOT INCLUDE ANY SUBRECIPIENTS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF MONTANA TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUNOFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES.  NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS.ACTIVITIES: THIS GRANT, WITH THE REQUISITE STATE MATCH, PROVIDES FOR STATE PROGRAM STAFF AND SUPPORT RESOURCES TO IMPLEMENT THE NPS MANAGEMENT PLAN. OBJECTIVES SUPPORTING THE GOAL INCLUDE:
- CONDUCT WATER QUALITY MONITORING AND BENEFICIAL USE ASSESSMENT TO INFORM NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION CONTROL PRIORITIES AND PROJECT EFFECTIVENESS; APPLY RESULT TOWARD DEVELOPMENT OF MAXIMUM DAILY LOADS (TMDLS)
- PROVIDE LEADERSHIP, ASSISTANCE, AND SUPPORT TO LOCAL WATERSHED GROUPS AND CONSERVATION DISTRICTS IN THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF WATERSHED RESTORATION PLANS INCLUDING ASSOCIATED TMDLS
- OFFER BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMP) ASSISTANCE FOR NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION CONTROL
- INFORM AND EDUCATE THE PUBLIC, LANDOWNERS, AND LAND MANAGERS OF THE NEED AND BENEFIT OF CONTROLLING NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION
- PREVENT GROUNDWATER POLLUTION DUE TO NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION
- MANAGE DATA AND INFORMATION COLLECTED THROUGHOUT NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT FOR REPORTING TO THE GRANT REPORTING AND TRACKING SYSTEM (GRTS), STORET/WQX NATIONAL DATA WAREHOUSE AND STATE'S WATER QUALITY INTEGRATED REPORT [305(B)/303(D) REPORT] SUBRECIPIENT:NO SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT.OUTCOMES:THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE THE PRIMARY INTERMEDIATE OUTCOMES ARE GAIN TO KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THE WATER QUALITY STANDARDS ATTAINMENT AND BENEFICIAL USE STATUS OF ASSESSED WATERS, REDUCTION IN NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF WATER QUALITY RESTORATION PROJECTS, THE DEVELOPMENT OF WATER QUALITY RESTORATION PLANS   ARE USED TO GUIDE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF BOTH REGULATORY AND NON-REGULATORY POLLUTION CONTROL ACTIVITIES TO RESTORE WATER QUALITY.

DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE ALL STATE RESIDENTS AND OCCUPANTS, BOTH PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY.

AND 1013020303). THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY PROMOTING AND IMPLEMENTING BMP THAT
ARE EFFECTIVE AT REDUCING IN-STREAM CONCENTRATIONS OF TOTAL SUSPENDED SOLID (TSS) AND E.
COLI BACTERIA. THE BMPS HAVE VARIED IN SCOPE AND OBJECTIVE WITH MOST RELATING TO

INFRASTRUCTURE, AND ROTATIONAL GRAZING SYSTEMS. A SECONDARY GOAL IS TO ALSO REDUCE MEAN
ANNUAL NITROGEN AND PHOSPHORUS CONCENTRATIONS AT STORET SITE 385078

IN THE MAINSTREAM OF THE KNIFE RIVER DOWNSTREAM FROM THE PROJECT. THE PROJECT GOAL WILL BE

IDENTIFIED AND ADDRESSED BY IMPLEMENTING ON-SITE MANURE MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS OR WINTERFEEDING
ROTATIONS THAT PREVENT MANURE ACCUMULATIONS AND ACCESS TO RIPARIAN CORRIDORS.

PROGRAMMING. DRAWING FROM AN EXISTING MULTI-GENERATIONAL POOL OF RANCHERS, INCLUDING MANY

NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION MANAGEMENT EFFORTS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF NORTH DAKOTA TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUNOFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES. NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS.ACTIVITIES:THIS GRANT IS USED FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF ACTIVITIES THAT ARE CONSISTENT WITH RECOMMENDATIONS DESCRIBED IN THE 2021 NORTH DAKOTA NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN. NORTH DAKOTA SUPPORTS AN EXTENSIVE SUBAWARD PROGRAM WHICH FUNDS PROJECTS ACROSS THE STATE TO ADDRESS NONPOINT SOURCE ISSUES. THESE IMPLEMENTATION ACTIVITIES OR PRACTICES ARE IDENTIFIED IN A DEQ-ACCEPTED WATERSHED PLAN. THESE PROJECTS ADDRESS IMPAIRMENTS IDENTIFIED ON NORTH DAKOTA'S LIST OF IMPAIRED WATERS. IN SOME INSTANCES, PROJECTS ON STREAMS THAT ARE NOT LISTED AS IMPAIRED MAY BE ACCEPTABLE. THESE PROJECTS MUST REDUCE POLLUTANT LOADING TO AN IMPAIRED, DOWNSTREAM RECEIVING WATER OR PROTECT EXISTING USES FROM BECOMING IMPAIRED.SUBRECIPIENT:THE 11 SUBAWARDS FUNDED IN THIS GRANT WILL FUND ON-THE-GROUND PROJECTS, OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES, LOCAL CAPACITY BUILDING, WATER QUALITY RESTORATION PROJECTS, WHICH ARE ALL DESIGNED TO ADDRESS NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION. OUTCOMES:THE 319 NONPOINT SOURCE PROGRAM PROVIDES FUNDING FOR DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF PROJECTS THAT REDUCE AND PREVENT NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION IN IMPAIRED WATERBODIES WHILE IMPROVING WATER QUALITY AND RESTORING NATURAL STREAM AND LAKE PROCESSES. THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES ARE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS THAT DESCRIBES THE WORK THAT HAS OCCURRED UNDER THE GRANT, DATA INPUT TO THE NATIONAL NONPOINT SOURCE DATABASE, EDUCATION AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES. THE EXPECTED ENVIRONMENTAL OUTCOMES INCLUDE REDUCTIONS IN SEDIMENT, NITROGEN AND PHOSPHORUS FROM FOURTEEN SUBAWARDS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARY IS CLEANER WATER IN RIVERS AND STREAMS, IMPROVED HABITAT FOR AQUATIC SPECIES AND HEALTHY WATERSHEDS ACROSS THE STATE OF MONTANA AND ALL STATE RESIDENTS AND OCCUPANTS WHO BENEFIT FROM HEALTHIER WATERSHEDS.

THE PROPOSED WORK IN THIS AGREEMENT INCLUDES: THREE PROJECTS THAT WILL SUPPORT SELENIUM REDUCTION BMPS (SUCH AS CONVERTING FLOOD TO SPRINKLERS, PIPING EARTHEN DITCHES, IMPROVING SOIL HEALTH AND IRRIGATED LANDS), IMPLEMENTING AGRICULTURAL BMPS (SUCH AS CONVERTING OPEN DIRT DITCH CANALS TO BURIED PIPELINES, INSTALLING OFF-CHANNEL WATER AND SEDIMENT BASINS, AND STABILIZING THE RIPARIAN AREA AND BANK THROUGH REVEGETATION AND STRUCTURES THAT PROMOTE A NATURALLY STABLE STREAM CHANNEL), AND SEDIMENT AND EROSION REDUCTION EFFORTS (SUCH AS IRRIGATION DIVERSION RECONSTRUCTION AND STREAM RESTORATION, IMPROVING STREAM STABILITY, WATER QUALITY, FISH HABITAT, AND FISH PASSAGE).SUBRECIPIENT:THE THREE SUBAWARDS FUNDED IN THIS GRANT WILL FUND ON-THE-GROUND PROJECTS, OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES, LOCAL CAPACITY BUILDING, AND WATER QUALITY RESTORATION PROJECTS, WHICH ARE ALL DESIGNED TO ADDRESS NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION.OUTCOMES:THE 319 NONPOINT SOURCE PROGRAM PROVIDES FUNDING FOR DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF PROJECTS THAT REDUCE AND PREVENT NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION IN IMPAIRED WATERBODIES WHILE IMPROVING WATER QUALITY AND RESTORING NATURAL STREAM AND LAKE PROCESSES. THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES ARE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS THAT DESCRIBES THE WORK THAT HAS OCCURRED UNDER THE GRANT, DATA INPUT TO THE NATIONAL NONPOINT SOURCE DATABASE, EDUCATION AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES. THE EXPECTED EXPECTED ENVIRONMENTAL OUTCOMES FROM THE SUBAWARDS INCLUDE: 
SUBAWARD 1: INSTALL LINING AND PIPING ON OPEN CANALS, LATERALS AND DITCHES, WATER AND STAGE CONTROL STRUCTURES AND AUTOMATION UNITS, IRRIGATION SCHEDULING BMPS, AND COVER CROP IMPLEMENTATION. SUBAWARD 1 IS EXPECTED TO REDUCE SELENIUM LOADING BY 1% WHILE THE COMBINED SEGMENTS WOULD REDUCE SELENIUM LOADING IN THE CASPER CREEK, OREGON TRAIL DRAIN, POISON SPIDER/SPRING CREEKS, AND NORTH PLATTE SUB-WATERSHEDS A MINIMUM OF 10% BY 2026 THROUGH IMPROVED IRRIGATION CONVEYANCE, ON-FARM APPLICATION SYSTEMS, IMPLEMENTATION OF COVER CROPS, AND IRRIGATION WATER MANAGEMENT.
SUBAWARD 2: INSTALL APPROXIMATELY 7,700 FEET OF PIPELINE TO REPLACE THE EXISTING ERODING EARTHEN MEYER'S DITCH, INSTALL SMALL RESERVOIRS ALONG PAINT ROCK CREEK TO PROVIDE OFF-CHANNEL WATER FOR LIVESTOCK/WILDLIFE AND CATCH SEDIMENT AND WATER DURING HIGH RUNOFF, AND INSTALL STREAM AND RIPARIAN RESTORATION PRACTICES TO IMPROVE BUFFER ZONE CONDITIONS, REDUCE EROSION, AND LIMIT ACCESSIBILITY FOR DIRECT DEFECATION. SUBAWARD 2 WILL PRIMARILY REDUCE FECAL COLIFORM LOADING TO PAINT ROCK CREEK BY INSTALLING SEVERAL BMPS TO ADDRESS CONTRIBUTIONS FROM RANGELAND, CROPLAND, AND RIPARIAN SOURCES. BECAUSE THERE IS ALSO A KNOWN ISSUE WITH EROSION THAT IS LIKELY ALLOWING MORE TRANSPORT OF E. COLI POLLUTANTS, THIS PROJECT WILL CONCURRENTLY WORK TO STABILIZE THE STREAM CHANNEL AND RIPARIAN AREA, WHICH WILL REDUCE SEDIMENT LOADING AND SLOW OVERLAND RUNOFF.
SUBAWARD 3: RECONSTRUCT A PERMANENT, SELF-MAINTAINING, FISH-PASSABLE ROCK CROSS-VANE IRRIGATION DIVE

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF WYOMING TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUNOFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES.  NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS.ACTIVITIES:THIS GRANT IS USED FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF ACTIVITIES THAT ARE CONSISTENT WITH RECOMMENDATIONS DESCRIBED IN THE WYOMING NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN. WYOMING SUPPORTS AN EXTENSIVE SUBAWARD PROGRAM WHICH FUNDS PROJECTS ACROSS THE STATE TO ADDRESS NONPOINT SOURCE ISSUES. THESE IMPLEMENTATION ACTIVITIES OR PRACTICES ARE IDENTIFIED IN A DEQ-ACCEPTED WATERSHED RESTORATION PLAN (WRP). THESE PROJECTS ADDRESS IMPAIRMENTS IDENTIFIED ON WYOMING'S LIST OF IMPAIRED WATERS. IN SOME INSTANCES, PROJECTS ON STREAMS THAT ARE NOT LISTED AS IMPAIRED MAY BE ACCEPTABLE. THESE PROJECTS MUST REDUCE POLLUTANT LOADING TO AN IMPAIRED, DOWNSTREAM RECEIVING WATER OR PROTECT EXISTING USES FROM BECOMING IMPAIRED.SUBRECIPIENT:THE 10 SUBAWARDS FUNDED IN THIS GRANT WILL FUND ON-THE-GROUND PROJECTS, OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES, LOCAL CAPACITY BUILDING, WATER QUALITY RESTORATION PROJECTS, WHICH ARE ALL DESIGNED TO ADDRESS NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION.OUTCOMES:THE 319 NONPOINT SOURCE PROGRAM PROVIDES FUNDING FOR DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF PROJECTS THAT REDUCE AND PREVENT NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION IN IMPAIRED WATERBODIES WHILE IMPROVING WATER QUALITY AND RESTORING NATURAL STREAM AND LAKE PROCESSES. THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES ARE ANNUAL AND FINAL REPORTS THAT DESCRIBES THE WORK THAT HAS OCCURRED UNDER THE GRANT, DATA INPUT TO THE NATIONAL NONPOINT SOURCE DATABASE, EDUCATION AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES. THE EXPECTED ENVIRONMENTAL OUTCOMES INCLUDE REDUCTIONS IN SEDIMENT, NITROGEN AND PHOSPHORUS FROM FOURTEEN SUBAWARDS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARY IS CLEANER WATER IN RIVERS AND STREAMS, IMPROVED HABITAT FOR AQUATIC SPECIES AND HEALTHY WATERSHEDS ACROSS THE STATE OF WYOMING AND ALL STATE RESIDENTS AND OCCUPANTS WHO BENEFIT FROM HEALTHIER WATERSHEDS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF MISSOURI TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUNOFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES.  NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS.ACTIVITIES:THIS GRANT AGREEMENT WILL HELP PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION, TRAINING, TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER, DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS, AND WATER QUALITY MONITORING TO IMPLEMENT AND ASSESS THE SUCCESS OF SPECIFIC NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION PREVENTION PROJECTS. THIS GRANT PROVIDES FUNDING TO THE MISSOURI DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (MODNR)  TO CARRY OUT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN. MODNR WILL PROTECT, MAINTAIN, AND IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF WATERBODIES THROUGHOUT THEIR STATE BY IMPLEMENTING BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT WILL REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE WATER POLLUTION AND BY EDUCATING RESOURCE MANAGERS, PUBLIC OFFICIALS, COMMUNITY LEADERS AND PRIVATE CITIZENS ABOUT THE EFFECTS OF HUMAN ACTIVITIES ON WATER QUALITY AND WHAT THEIR COMMUNITIES CAN DO TO PREVENT AND REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION. MANY OF THE PROJECTS MODNR IMPLEMENTS TO REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION WILL INVOLVE THE USE OF GRANT SUBRECIPIENTS. THE ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE PREVENTING DEGRADATION OF UNIMPAIRED WATERBODIES AND REDUCING THE NUMBER OF IMPAIRED WATERBODIES IN THE STATE AND IMPROVING WATER QUALITY IN STATES/COMMUNITIES DOWNSTREAM.SUBRECIPIENT:THE ACTIVITIES TO BE IMPLEMENTED THROUGH SUBAWARDS INCLUDE ACTIVITIES THAT AID IN ACCOMPLISHING THE OBJECTIVES OF THE MISSOURI NONPOINT SOURCE (NPS) MANAGEMENT PLAN. THESE ACTIVITIES WILL FOCUS ON SPECIFIC TMDLS AND STREAM SEGMENTS TO DELIST THROUGH A STRATEGIC PLANNING PROCESS. THESE STRATEGIES INCLUDED INNOVATIVE BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), INFORMATION/EDUCATION, PARTNERSHIPS, DEVELOPMENT OF WATER QUALITY PROTECTION PLANS, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF WATER QUALITY BMPS FOR ACTIVITIES AND PROJECTS NOT ADDRESSED THROUGH OTHER PROGRAMS THAT COULD ADVERSELY AFFECT WATER QUALITY.OUTCOMES:MODNR WILL PROVIDE THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES: FINAL REPORTS BASED ON PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION PLANS, PROGRAM ANNUAL REPORTS, GRANT ANNUAL PERFORMANCE REPORTS, LOAD REDUCTION DATA, NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS, PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION PLANS, AND WATERSHED BASED PLANS. MODNR WILL PROTECT, MAINTAIN, AND IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF WATERBODIES THROUGHOUT THEIR STATE BY IMPLEMENTING BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT WILL REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE WATER POLLUTION AND BY EDUCATING RESOURCE MANAGERS, PUBLIC OFFICIALS, COMMUNITY LEADERS AND PRIVATE CITIZENS ABOUT THE EFFECTS OF HUMAN ACTIVITIES ON WATER QUALITY AND WHAT THEIR COMMUNITIES CAN DO TO PREVENT AND REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION. THE ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE PREVENTING DEGRADATION OF UNIMPAIRED WATERBODIES AND REDUCING THE NUMBER OF IMPAIRED WATERBODIES IN THE STATE AND IMPROVING WATER QUALITY IN STATES/COMMUNITIES DOWNSTREAM. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE ALL STATE RESIDENTS AND OCCUPANTS, BOTH PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY.

DESCRIPTION:THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF NEBRASKA TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUNOFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES.  NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS.ACTIVITIES:THE PROPOSED WORK IN THIS AGREEMENT  INCLUDES: PROJECTS THAT WILL SUPPORT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE, EDUCATION, TRAINING, TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER, DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS, AND WATER QUALITY MONITORING TO IMPLEMENT AND ASSESS THE SUCCESS OF SPECIFIC NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION PREVENTION PROJECTS. THIS GRANT PROVIDES FUNDING TO THE NEBRASKA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENT AND ENERGY (NDEE) TO CARRY OUT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN. NDEE WILL PROTECT, MAINTAIN, AND IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF WATERBODIES THROUGHOUT THEIR STATE BY IMPLEMENTING BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT WILL REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE WATER POLLUTION AND BY EDUCATING RESOURCE MANAGERS, PUBLIC OFFICIALS, COMMUNITY LEADERS AND PRIVATE CITIZENS ABOUT THE EFFECTS OF HUMAN ACTIVITIES ON WATER QUALITY AND WHAT THEIR COMMUNITIES CAN DO TO PREVENT AND REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION. MANY OF THE PROJECTS NDEE IMPLEMENTS TO REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION WILL INVOLVE THE USE OF GRANT SUBRECIPIENTS. THE ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE PREVENTING DEGRADATION OF UNIMPAIRED WATERBODIES AND REDUCING THE NUMBER OF IMPAIRED WATERBODIES IN THE STATE AND IMPROVING WATER QUALITY IN STATES/COMMUNITIES DOWNSTREAM.SUBRECIPIENT:THE ACTIVITIES TO BE IMPLEMENTED THROUGH SUBAWARDS INCLUDE ACTIVITIES THAT AID IN ACCOMPLISHING THE OBJECTIVES OF THE NEBRASKA NONPOINT SOURCE (NPS) MANAGEMENT PLAN. THESE ACTIVITIES WILL FOCUS ON SPECIFIC IMPAIRMENTS AND TMDLS DELIST THROUGH A STRATEGIC PLANNING PROCESS. THESE STRATEGIES INCLUDED INNOVATIVE BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), INFORMATION/EDUCATION, PARTNERSHIPS, DEVELOPMENT OF WATER QUALITY PROTECTION PLANS, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF WATER QUALITY BMPS FOR ACTIVITIES AND PROJECTS NOT ADDRESSED THROUGH OTHER PROGRAMS THAT COULD ADVERSELY AFFECT WATER QUALITY.OUTCOMES:NDEE WILL PROVIDE THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES: FINAL REPORTS BASED ON PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION PLANS, PROGRAM ANNUAL REPORTS, GRANT ANNUAL PERFORMANCE REPORTS, LOAD REDUCTION DATA, NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS, PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION PLANS, AND WATERSHED BASED PLANS. NDEE WILL PROTECT, MAINTAIN, AND IMPROVE THE WATER QUALITY OF WATERBODIES THROUGHOUT THEIR STATE BY IMPLEMENTING BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT WILL REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE WATER POLLUTION AND BY EDUCATING RESOURCE MANAGERS, PUBLIC OFFICIALS, COMMUNITY LEADERS AND PRIVATE CITIZENS ABOUT THE EFFECTS OF HUMAN ACTIVITIES ON WATER QUALITY AND WHAT THEIR COMMUNITIES CAN DO TO PREVENT AND REDUCE NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION. THE ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE PREVENTING DEGRADATION OF UNIMPAIRED WATERBODIES AND REDUCING THE NUMBER OF IMPAIRED WATERBODIES IN THE STATE AND IMPROVING WATER QUALITY IN STATES/COMMUNITIES DOWNSTREAM.

DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE ALL STATE RESIDENTS AND OCCUPANTS, BOTH PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO PROVIDE WEST VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION'S WATERSHED IMPROVEMENT BRANCH WITH FEDERAL FUNDS IN THE AMOUNT OF $1,855,000, $10,000 OF WHICH ARE IN-KIND FUNDS. THIS AWARD PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE STATE OF WEST VIRGINIA TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUNOFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES. NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS.ACTIVITIES:THE PROPOSED WORK IN THIS AGREEMENT  INCLUDES NINE (9) PROJECTS THAT WILL SUPPORT THE STATE'S PURSUIT OF LONG-TERM NONPOINT SOURCE POLLUTION REDUCTION THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF BMPS THAT ADDRESS AND REDUCE TOTAL MAXIMUM DAILY LOADS (TMDLS) OF PRIORITY POLLUTANTS, COORDINATION WITH PARTNER AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS TO IMPLEMENT PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION, WATERSHED AND SOURCE WATER PLANNING, TREATMENT OF ACID MINE DRAINAGE, AND THE REDUCTION OF BACTERIA THROUGH SEPTIC REMEDIATION AND REPAIR.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE (GI) PROJECTS MODELING THE INTEGRATION OF SOURCE WATER PROTECTION PLANS (SWPPS) INTO COMPREHENSIVE WATERSHED BASED PLANS (WBPS), INSTALLATION AND IMPROVEMENTS TO AMD PASSIVE TREATMENT SYSTEMS, WASTEWATER INFRASTRUCTURE IMPROVEMENTS, PUBLIC OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES, AND ADDITIONAL ACTIVITIES AS DEEMED NECESSARY TO THE SUCCESS OF THE NPS PROGRAM. SUBRECIPIENT:ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE (GI) PROJECTS MODELING THE INTEGRATION OF SOURCE WATER PROTECTION PLANS (SWPPS) INTO COMPREHENSIVE WATERSHED BASED PLANS (WBPS), INSTALLATION AND IMPROVEMENTS TO AMD PASSIVE TREATMENT SYSTEMS, WASTEWATER INFRASTRUCTURE IMPROVEMENTS, PUBLIC OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES, AND ADDITIONAL ACTIVITIES AS DEEMED NECESSARY TO THE SUCCESS OF THE NPS PROGRAM. OUTCOMES:THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES ARE PROJECT-DEPENDENT. EACH PROJECT AIMS TO REDUCE, OR TO CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS THE REDUCTION OF, TOTAL LOADS OF NITROGEN, PHOSPHORUS, PATHOGENS, SEDIMENTS, AND METALS IN THEIR WATERSHEDS, IMPROVE PH AND WATER QUALITY INDICATORS TO RESTORE ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, REMOVE BODIES OF WATER FROM LIST OF IMPAIRED WATERWAYS, REDUCE HUMAN HEALTH RISKS, AND IMPROVE THE ECONOMIC POTENTIAL OF THE WATERSHED. 

DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE ALL WEST VIRGINIA RESIDENTS, VISITORS, AND BUSINESSES, BOTH PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY, AS WELL AS THE WATERSHEDS AND ENVIRONMENTS WITHIN THE STATE.

DESCRIPTION:THIS GRANT AWARD AGREEMENT PROVIDES FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE AND SUPPORT TO THE COMMONWEALTH OF VIRGINIA TO IMPLEMENT ITS  319 NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUNOFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES.  NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS.ACTIVITIES:THE PROPOSED WORK IN THIS AGREEMENT INCLUDES NINE (9) PROJECTS THAT WILL SUPPORT BACTERIA, NUTRIENT, AND SEDIMENT LOAD REDUCTIONS, COORDINATION WITH PARTNER AGENCIES AND NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANNING. NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS WILL BE CONDUCTED BY BOTH THE STATE GRANT RECIPIENT AS WELL AS SUBRECIPIENTS, AND INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS. THE PROJECTS TO BE FUNDED WITH THIS GRANT AWARD WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT PROJECTS AND BMPS PRIMARILY IN THE AREAS OF CONSERVATION PLANNING, NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT, POLLUTANT LOAD REDUCTIONS, WATERSHED PLAN IMPLEMENTATION, AND DITCH/WETLAND/STREAM RESTORATION.SUBRECIPIENT:THE ACTIVITIES TO BE IMPLEMENTED THROUGH SUBAWARDS TO MULTIPLE RECIPIENTS WILL PRIMARILY INCLUDE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF ON THE GROUND BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AIMED AT IMPROVING WATER QUALITY IN NONPOINT SOURCE IMPAIRED WATERBODIES AS GUIDED BY EPA ACCEPTED WATERSHED-BASED PLANS. OF THE $1,759,850 IN TOTAL SUBAWARDS, A SUBAWARD OF $60,000 WILL BE MADE TO THE SAINT REGIS MOHAWK TRIBE FOR THE 2024 NORTHEAST REGIONAL WATER SUMMIT FOR TRIBES AND NATIONS, WHICH IS FUNDED BY A SPECIAL SOLICITATION WITH SUPPLEMENTAL FUNDING.OUTCOMES:THE ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES INCLUDE POLLUTANT LOAD REDUCTIONS IN WATERSHEDS WITH CLEAN WATER ACT SECTION 319 APPROVED WATERSHED-BASED PLANS, ULTIMATELY LEADING TO RESTORATION OF WATERBODIES AND ATTAINMENT OF WATER QUALITY STANDARDS. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT BMP INSTALLATIONS SUCH AS LIVESTOCK STREAM EXCLUSIONS AND SEPTIC IMPROVEMENTS WILL RESULT IN THE REDUCTION OF MILLIONS OF POUNDS OF NITROGEN AND PHOSPHORUS, HUNDREDS OF THOUSANDS OF TONS OF SEDIMENT AND A SIGNIFICANT AMOUNT OF BACTERIA FROM ENTERING TARGETED WATERSHEDS.

ADDITIONAL ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES INCLUDE WATERSHED ROUNDTABLE SUPPORT, A NORTHEAST WATER TRAINING FOR TRIBES AND NATIONS (FUNDED BY A $60,000 SPECIAL SOLICITATION SUPPLEMENT), TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND DATABASE DEVELOPMENT. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE ALL COMMONWEALTH RESIDENTS AND OCCUPANTS, BOTH PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY.

DESCRIPTION:THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE SUPPORT TO THE COMMONWEALTH OF PENNSYLVANIA IN IMPLEMENTING ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUN-OFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES. NONPOINT SOURCE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS CAN BE CONDUCTED BY BOTH THE STATE GRANT RECIPIENT AS WELL AS BY A VARIETY OF SUB-RECIPIENTS, AND INCLUDE A VARIETY OF STRUCTURAL AND NON-STRUCTURAL BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), WATERSHED PLANNING, MONITORING, TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS, AND A VARIETY OF EDUCATION/OUTREACH PROGRAMS. 

THIS ACTION AWARDS FEDERAL FUNDS OF $4,967,300 PLUS AN ADDITIONAL $10,000 OF EPA IN-KIND FUNDING.ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE THE DESIGN, PERMITTING, OR IMPLEMENTATION OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO REDUCE POLLUTANT LOADING FROM ABANDONED MINE DRAINAGE, AGRICULTURE, AND STREAM DEGRADATION, WATERSHED-BASED PLAN DEVELOPMENT AND REVISIONS, AND STREAM AND LAKE MONITORING/ASSESSMENTS PROJECTS.SUBRECIPIENT:PROPOSED SUBAGREEMENT WORK IN THIS GRANT INCLUDES THE DESIGN, PERMITTING, OR IMPLEMENTATION OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO REDUCE POLLUTANT LOADING FROM ABANDON MINE DRAINAGE, AGRICULTURE, AND STREAM DEGRADATION, WATERSHED BASED PLAN DEVELOPMENT AND REVISIONS, AND STREAM AND LAKE MONITORING/ASSESSMENTS PROJECTS.OUTCOMES:ANTICIPATED DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES INCLUDE COMPLETED DESIGN/PERMITTING FOR FUTURE BMP IMPLEMENTATION, COMPLETED BMP IMPLEMENTATION, EPA ACCEPTED WATERSHED-BASED PLAN REVISIONS OR NEW WATERSHED-BASED PLANS, AND STREAM/LAKE MONITORING DATA UPLOADED TO WQX. IN ADDITION TO THESE EXPECTED OUTCOMES, OTHER DELIVERABLES INCLUDE TWO SEMI-ANNUAL REPORTS, ONE ANNUAL REPORT, FINAL REPORTS FOR ALL COMPLETED 319 PROJECTS UNDER THE AWARD, AND 2 319 PROGRAM SUCCESS STORIES. THE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS ARE EXPECTED TO PRIMARILY ACHIEVE POLLUTANT LOAD REDUCTIONS IN WATERSHEDS WITH CLEAN WATER ACT SECTION 319 APPROVED WATERSHED-BASED PLANS, ULTIMATELY LEADING TO RESTORATION OF WATERBODIES AND ATTAINMENT OF WATER QUALITY STANDARDS. THE BENEFICIARIES ARE CITIZENS IN THE STATE OF PENNSYLVANIA.

DESCRIPTION:THIS 319(H) ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES $1,062,000.00 OF FEDERAL FUNDS IN FULL, TO INCLUDE $10,000.00 OF IN-KIND SUPPORT, TO IMPLEMENT THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA'S NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM AS OUTLINED IN THEIR EPA APPROVED NPS MANAGEMENT PLAN.  IT PROVIDES SUPPORT TO THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA TO IMPLEMENT ITS NPS PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON RESTORING WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUN-OFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES.  ACTIVITIES:NPS PROJECTS CAN BE CONDUCTED BY BOTH THE STATE GRANT RECIPIENT AS WELL AS BY A VARIETY OF SUBRECIPIENTS.  THE PROJECTS TO BE FUNDED WITH THIS GRANT AWARD WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT PROJECTS AND BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS) IN THE AREAS OF CONSERVATION PLANNING, NUTRIENT MANAGEMENT, NUTRIENT LOAD REDUCTIONS, WATERSHED PLAN IMPLEMENTATION, AND DITCH/WETLAND/STREAM RESTORATION. ACTIVITIES WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED UNDER THIS GRANT AWARD THAT FURTHER THE RECIPIENT'S EFFORTS IN PARTIALLY OR FULLY RESTORING WATERBODIES THAT HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED BY DC AS BEING PRIMARILY NPS-IMPAIRED.SUBRECIPIENT:THE RECIPIENT ALSO INTENDS TO USE A SUBAWARD TO RUN THE DC WATERSHED LID RETROFIT PROGRAM WHICH WAS DESIGNED TO IMPLEMENT LID AND OTHER INNOVATIVE URBAN NPS BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES (BMPS), AS WELL AS TARGETED STORMWATER RETROFITS FOR THE PURPOSE OF MEETING WATER QUALITY STANDARDS IN DISTRICT WATERBODIES. LASTLY, THE RECIPIENT WILL USE A SUBAWARD TO SUPPORT TWO U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY GAUGE STATIONS AT WATTS BRANCH AND ROCK CREEK THROUGH A MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING WITH THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY (USGS).OUTCOMES:THE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECTS ARE EXPECTED TO PRIMARILY ACHIEVE POLLUTANT LOAD REDUCTIONS IN WATERSHEDS WITH CLEAN WATER ACT SECTION 319 APPROVED WATERSHED-BASED PLANS, ULTIMATELY LEADING TO RESTORATION OF WATERBODIES AND ATTAINMENT OF WATER QUALITY STANDARDS. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE ALL DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA RESIDENTS AND OCCUPANTS, BOTH PERMANENT AND TEMPORARY.

DESCRIPTION:THIS 319(H) GRANT AWARD AGREEMENT PROVIDES FEDERAL FUNDS IN THE AMOUNT OF $1,181,000.00, WITH $10,000 IN-KIND SUPPORT TO THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA TO IMPLEMENT ITS NONPOINT SOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, FOCUSING ON RESTORING WATERSHEDS WITH WATER QUALITY IMPAIRMENTS CAUSED BY POLLUTED RUN-OFF FROM NONPOINT SOURCES.
